questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female at 30 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with complaints of severe pruritus, particularly on her palms and soles, without any associated rash. She also reports dark urine and pale stools. On examination, her skin and sclerae are mildly jaundiced. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum bile acids and mildly elevated liver transaminases. Which of the following mutations is not typically associated with the condition?
questions.correct_answer: D. LCHAD (long-chain 3-hydroxy acyl-CoA dehydrogenase) gene mutation
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)

Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (IHCP)

Pathogenesis

Defective fatty acid oxidation due to mitochondrial enzyme dysfunction (e.g., LCHAD mutation).

Impaired bile acid secretion due to mutations in bile transport genes

  • ABCB4 and ABCB11 gene (Option A & B)
  • Bile salt export pump (BSEP)
  • Multidrug resistance protein 3 (MDR3) (Option C)

Onset

Typically occurs in the third trimester

Usually manifests in the second or third trimester.

Symptoms

Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, jaundice, hypoglycemia.

Severe pruritus (especially on palms and soles), dark urine, pale stools, mild jaundice.

Complications

Acute liver failure, renal failure, encephalopathy, coagulopathy, maternal and fetal death.

Preterm delivery, fetal distress, increased risk of stillbirth.

Lab findings and diagnosis
  • Elevated liver enzymes, hypoglycemia, coagulopathy, elevated ammonia levels
  • Diagnosis confirmed by liver biopsy if necessary.
  • Elevated serum bile acids, and mildly elevated liver enzymes.
  • Elevated serum bile acids >10 µmol/L; exclusion of other liver diseases is the mainstay of diagnosis

Treatment

Immediate delivery and supportive care with management of complications.

Ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) to reduce bile acids and early delivery if needed.

Prognosis

High maternal and fetal mortality without prompt treatment.

Good prognosis with proper management, though there is a risk of recurrence in subsequent pregnancies.

questions.text: Which statement regarding the Intrahepatic Cholestasis of Pregnancy (ICP) is false?

options.label: A
options.text: ICP is characterised by pruritus and pale stools

questions.explanation:
Risk Factors
  • Personal or family history of ICP
  • Multiple gestations
  • Hepatitis C infection

Clinical Features
  • Pruritus, especially on the palms and soles
  • Jaundice (in some cases)
  • Dark urine
  • Pale stools
  • Fatigue
  • Right upper quadrant abdominal pain

Diagnosis
  • Elevated serum bile acids (≤10 mg/dL)
  • Elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST)
  • Exclusion of other causes of liver dysfunction

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant female at 30 weeks gestation presents to the clinic with complaints of severe pruritus, particularly on her palms and soles, without any associated rash. She also reports dark urine and pale stools. On examination, her skin and sclerae are mildly jaundiced. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated serum bile acids and mildly elevated liver transaminases. Which among the following is wrong about the management of the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Ursodeoxycholic acid reduces liver enzymes and relieves symptoms

options.label: B
options.text: Cholestyramine and antihistamines are first-line therapy for pruritus.

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin K to reduce postpartum haemorrhage and neonatal bleeding

questions.correct_answer: B. Cholestyramine and antihistamines are first-line therapy for pruritus.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida at 36 weeks of gestation presents with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, jaundice, and extreme fatigue. On physical examination, she appears icteric, and her liver is mildly tender but not enlarged. Laboratory tests reveal AST & ALT >200 IU/L, Total Bilirubin 5.5 mg/dL, PT 18 seconds, Serum Creatinine 2.5mg/dl, and Blood Glucose 55 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Acute Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (AFLP)
questions.explanation:
Definition

A rare, life-threatening liver disorder that occurs in the third trimester of pregnancy, characterised by microvesicular fatty infiltration of hepatocytes.

Risk Factors
  • First pregnancy
  • Multiple gestations
  • Male fetus
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Maternal obesity
  • Prior history of AFLP

Clinical Features
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice
  • Malaise and fatigue
  • Anorexia
  • Polydipsia and polyuria
  • Ascites (rare)

Complications
  • Liver failure
  • Renal failure
  • Coagulopathy
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Encephalopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery of the baby (definitive treatment)
  • Supportive care for the mother: IV fluids, glucose infusion, and blood products for coagulopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the aetiopathogenesis of acute fatty liver of pregnancy?

options.label: B
options.text: Accumulation of fat in liver cells

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the diagnosis of AFLP?
questions.explanation:
Category

Feature

Clinical Features
  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia/polyuria
  • Encephalopathy

Lab Features
  • Elevated bilirubin (>0.8 mg/dL)
  • Hypoglycemia (<72 mg/dL)
  • Elevated urate
  • Leukocytosis (>11,000/μL)
  • Elevated transaminases (AST or ALT >42 IU/L)
  • Ammonia >47 μmol/L
  • Renal impairment (creatinine >1.7mg/dl)
  • Coagulopathy (PT >14 s or APTT >34 s)
  • Urea >340 μmol/L

USG

Ascites

Histology

Microvesicular steatosis on liver biopsy

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman, a known case of PIH, at 34 weeks of gestation, presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe right upper quadrant abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and headaches. She has a history of hypertension during pregnancy. On examination, her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg, and she has significant oedema in her lower extremities. Which of the following is not a finding of this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: LDH levels greater than 600 IU/L are indicative of hemolysis

options.label: B
options.text: Elevated AST levels greater than 70 IU/L

options.label: C
options.text: Elevated bilirubin levels of more than 1.2 mg/dL

questions.explanation:
Haemolysis
  • Abnormal peripheral blood smear
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH > 600 IU/L)
  • Elevated bilirubin (≥ 1.2 mg/dL)
  • Decreased serum haptoglobin

Elevated Liver Enzymes
  • Elevated (AST & ALT > 70 IU/L)

Low Platelet Count
  • Platelets < 100,000/μL

Mississippi Triple Class System

Class I (severe)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets <50 x 109 /L

Class II (moderate)
  • AST & ALT > 70 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 50-100 x 109 /L

Class III (mild)
  • AST & ALT > 40 IU/L
  • LDH > 600 IU/L
  • Platelets 100-150 x 109 /L

Risk Factors

Clinical Features

Complications
  • History of preeclampsia or HELLP syndrome
  • Multiparity
  • Advanced maternal age
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes
  • Chronic hypertension
  • Right upper quadrant or epigastric pain
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Malaise
  • Headache
  • Visual disturbances
  • Hypertension
  • Proteinuria

Mother:

  • Liver hematoma or rupture
  • Acute renal failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Placental abruption

Fetus:

  • Preterm birth
  • IUGR or Stillbirth

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman, multiparous and obese, presents with sudden onset right upper quadrant pain, nausea, and visual disturbances. She has a history of chronic hypertension and diabetes. On examination, she is hypertensive with proteinuria. Initial lab reports show low platelets, elevated liver enzymes & evidence of hemolysis on peripheral smear. Which of these statements regarding the management of her condition is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate delivery if gestational age is 34 weeks or more

options.label: B
options.text: Antihypertensive therapy to target blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg

options.label: C
options.text: Corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturity if the pregnancy is <34 weeks

questions.correct_answer: B. Antihypertensive therapy to target blood pressure of 110/70 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of hyperemesis gravidarum?
questions.explanation:
Hormonal Factors
  • Elevated levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG)
  • Elevated levels of estrogen
  • Progesterone causes gastrointestinal relaxation

Multiple Gestation
  • Twins or triplets (higher levels of hCG)

Molar Pregnancy
  • Hydatidiform mole (excessive hCG production)

Gastrointestinal Factors
  • Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD)
  • Helicobacter pylori infection

Psychological Factors
  • Stress & Anxiety

Genetic Factors
  • Family history of hyperemesis gravidarum

Metabolic Factors
  • Hyperthyroidism

Other Factors
  • Vitamin B6 deficiency
  • Increased sensitivity to certain odours

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman nullipara in her first trimester of pregnancy presents to the clinic with nausea and vomiting which is insidious in onset, vomiting occurs throughout the day. Normal day-to-day activities are curtailed. There is no evidence of dehydration or starvation. What is the recommended first-line treatment for her condition?
questions.explanation:
First-Line Treatments

Dietary Modifications

Small, frequent meals; bland, low-fat, high-protein foods; avoiding triggers; ginger (ginger ale, ginger tea)

Hydration & Electrolyte Management

Oral rehydration solutions, intravenous fluids, and electrolyte replacement

Pharmacological Rx

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine); Doxylamine-pyridoxine combination (Diclegis)

Second-Line Treatments

Pharmacological Treatments
  • Antihistamines (e.g., diphenhydramine)
  • Antiemetics (e.g., ondansetron, promethazine); metoclopramide
  • Corticosteroids: e.g., methylprednisolone (Refractory cases)

Nutritional Support
  • Enteral nutrition (nasogastric or nasojejunal tube)
  • Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)

Alternative Therapy

Acupuncture, hypnotherapy

Psychological

Counseling and stress management techniques

Hospitalisation

For severe cases requiring intensive treatment

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman in her third trimester of pregnancy presents to the emergency department with a two-week history of jaundice, malaise, and dark urine. She also reports nausea and right upper quadrant pain. On examination, she is found to have hepatomegaly and mild ascites. Her laboratory results show significantly elevated liver enzymes, bilirubin (11 mg/dL), prolonged prothrombin time and normal serum creatinine. Serology was conducted, suggesting severe hepatitis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Hepatitis E is caused by the hepatitis E virus (HEV), which is primarily transmitted through the fecal-oral route, often through contaminated water. It can cause acute liver inflammation.

Aetiology

The hepatitis E virus (RNA virus)

  • Genotypes 1 & 2 cause outbreaks in developing countries.
  • Genotypes 3 & 4 in developed countries.

Pathogenesis
  • HEV enters the body through the gastrointestinal tract, replicates in the liver, and is shed in bile and faeces.
  • In pregnancy, particularly in the third trimester, the virus can lead to severe liver disease and fulminant hepatitis.

Clinical Features
  • Jaundice
  • Fatigue
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Anorexia
  • Abdominal pain
  • Fever
  • Dark urine and pale stools

Diagnosis
  • Markedly elevated liver enzymes (ALT, AST)
  • Elevated bilirubin ( around 6-15 mg/dL)
  • Serology: Anti-HEV IgM (acute infection) and Anti-HEV IgG (past infection)
  • HEV RNA detection in blood or stool by PCR

Complications

Mother

  • Fulminant hepatitis
  • Acute liver failure
  • Increased mortality (especially in the third trimester)

Fetus

  • Preterm birth
  • Low birth weight
  • IUD

Management
  • No specific antiviral treatment is approved for HEV
  • Supportive care: Hydration, rest, and nutritional support
  • Hospitalisation for severe cases

Prognosis

Poorer prognosis in pregnant women, particularly in the third trimester, with higher maternal and fetal mortality
